trans-unit.source: The <xref uid="langword_csharp_Financial" name="Financial" href=""></xref> module contains procedures used to perform financial operations.
This module supports the Visual Basic run-time library members that perform financial calculations such as depreciation, present and future values, interest rates, rates of return, and payments.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the depreciation of an asset for a specific time period using the double-declining balance method or some other method you specify.
The double-declining balance method computes depreciation at an accelerated rate.
Depreciation is highest in the first period and decreases in successive periods.
The `Life` and `Period` arguments must be expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Life` is given in months, `Period` must also be given in months.
All arguments must be positive numbers.
The `DDB` function uses the following formula to calculate depreciation for a given period: Depreciation / Period = ((Cost – Salvage) * Factor) / Life
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying initial cost of the asset.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying value of the asset at the end of its useful life.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying length of useful life of the asset.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying period for which asset depreciation is calculated.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying rate at which the balance declines.
If omitted, 2 (double-declining method) is assumed.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the depreciation of an asset for a specific time period using the double-declining balance method or some other method you specify.
Factor <= 0, Salvage < 0, Period <= 0, or Period > Life.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the future value of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
The `Rate` and `NPer` arguments must be calculated using payment periods expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Rate` is calculated using months, `NPer` must also be calculated using months.
For all arguments, cash paid out (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has a total of 4 x 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying payment to be made each period.
Payments usually contain principal and interest that doesn't change over the life of the annuity.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying present value (or lump sum) of a series of future payments.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.

This argument must be either <xref uid="langword_csharp_DueDate.EndOfPeriod" name="DueDate.EndOfPeriod" href=""></xref> if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_DueDate.BegOfPeriod" name="DueDate.BegOfPeriod" href=""></xref> if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, <xref uid="langword_csharp_DueDate.EndOfPeriod" name="DueDate.EndOfPeriod" href=""></xref> is assumed.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the future value of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the interest payment for a given period of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
The `Rate` and `NPer` arguments must be calculated using payment periods expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Rate` is calculated using months, `NPer` must also be calculated using months.
For all arguments, cash paid out (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying payment period in the range 1 through `NPer`.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has a total of 4 x 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying present value, or value today, of a series of future payments or receipts.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying future value or cash balance you want after you've made the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that's its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 over 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the interest payment for a given period of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
Per <= 0 or Per > NPer
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the internal rate of return for a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts).
The internal rate of return is the interest rate received for an investment consisting of payments and receipts that occur at regular intervals.
The `IRR` function uses the order of values within the array to interpret the order of payments and receipts.
Be sure to enter your payment and receipt values in the correct sequence.
The cash flow for each period does not need to be fixed, as it is for an annuity.
`IRR` is calculated by iteration.
Starting with the value of `Guess`, `IRR` cycles through the calculation until the result is accurate to within 0.00001 percent.
If `IRR` cannot find a result after 20 tries, it fails.
Required.
Array of <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying cash flow values.
The array must contain at least one negative value (a payment) and one positive value (a receipt).
Optional.
Object specifying value you estimate will be returned by <xref uid="langword_csharp_IRR" name="IRR" href=""></xref>.
If omitted, `Guess` is 0.1 (10 percent).
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the internal rate of return for a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts).
Array argument values are invalid or Guess <= -1.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the modified internal rate of return for a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts).
The modified internal rate of return is the internal rate of return when payments and receipts are financed at different rates.
The `MIRR` function takes into account both the cost of the investment (`FinanceRate`) and the interest rate received on reinvestment of cash (`ReinvestRate`).
The `FinanceRate` and `ReinvestRatearguments` are percentages expressed as decimal values.
For example, 12 percent is expressed as 0.12.
The `MIRR` function uses the order of values within the array to interpret the order of payments and receipts.
Be sure to enter your payment and receipt values in the correct sequence.
Required.
Array of <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying cash-flow values.
The array must contain at least one negative value (a payment) and one positive value (a receipt).
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying interest rate paid as the cost of financing.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying interest rate received on gains from cash reinvestment.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the modified internal rate of return for a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts).
Rank of ValueArray does not equal 1, FinanceRate = -1, or ReinvestRate = -1
Division by zero has occurred.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the number of periods for an annuity based on periodic fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over a period of time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
For all arguments, cash paid out (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying payment to be made each period.
Payments usually contain principal and interest that does not change over the life of the annuity.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying present value, or value today, of a series of future payments or receipts.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying future value or cash balance you want after you have made the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that is its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 over 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the number of periods for an annuity based on periodic fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
Rate = 0 and Pmt = 0

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the net present value of an investment based on a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts) and a discount rate.
The net present value of an investment is the current value of a future series of payments and receipts.
The `NPV` function uses the order of values within the array to interpret the order of payments and receipts.
Be sure to enter your payment and receipt values in the correct sequence.
The `NPV` investment begins one period before the date of the first cash flow value and ends with the last cash flow value in the array.
The net present value calculation is based on future cash flows.
If your first cash flow occurs at the beginning of the first period, the first value must be added to the value returned by `NPV` and must not be included in the cash flow values of `ValueArray`.
The `NPV` function is similar to the `PV` function (present value) except that the `PV` function allows cash flows to begin either at the end or the beginning of a period.
Unlike the variable `NPV` cash flow values, `PV` cash flows must be fixed throughout the investment.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying discount rate over the length of the period, expressed as a decimal.
Required.
Array of <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying cash flow values.
The array must contain at least one negative value (a payment) and one positive value (a receipt).

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the net present value of an investment based on a series of periodic cash flows (payments and receipts) and a discount rate.
ValueArray is , rank of ValueArray <> 1, or Rate = -1
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the payment for an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made during a period of time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
The `Rate` and `NPer` arguments must be calculated using payment periods expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Rate` is calculated using months, `NPer` must also be calculated using months.
For all arguments, cash paid (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has a total of 4 × 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the present value (or lump sum) that a series of payments to be paid in the future is worth now.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying future value or cash balance you want after you have made the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that is its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 during 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the payment for an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
NPer = 0.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the principal payment for a given period of an annuity based on periodic fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over a period of time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
The `Rate` and `NPer` arguments must be calculated using payment periods expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Rate` is calculated using months, `NPer` must also be calculated using months.
For all arguments, cash paid (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the payment period in the range 1 through `NPer`.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has a total of 4 x 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the current value of a series of future payments or receipts.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying future value or cash balance you want after you have made the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that is its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 over 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the principal payment for a given period of an annuity based on periodic fixed payments and a fixed interest rate.
Per <=0 or Per > NPer.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the present value of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments to be paid in the future and a fixed interest rate.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over a period of time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
The `Rate` and `NPer` arguments must be calculated using payment periods expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Rate` is calculated using months, `NPer` must also be calculated using months.
For all arguments, cash paid out (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the interest rate per period.
For example, if you get a car loan at an annual percentage rate (APR) of 10 percent and make monthly payments, the rate per period is 0.1/12, or 0.0083.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has 4 x 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the payment to be made each period.
Payments usually contain principal and interest that does not change during the life of the annuity.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the future value or cash balance you want after you make the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that is its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 over 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.

Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the present value of an annuity based on periodic, fixed payments to be paid in the future and a fixed interest rate.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the interest rate per period for an annuity.
An annuity is a series of fixed cash payments made over a period of time.
An annuity can be a loan (such as a home mortgage) or an investment (such as a monthly savings plan).
For all arguments, cash paid out (such as deposits to savings) is represented by negative numbers; cash received (such as dividend checks) is represented by positive numbers.
`Rate` is calculated by iteration.
Starting with the value of `Guess`, `Rate` cycles through the calculation until the result is accurate to within 0.00001 percent.
If `Rate` cannot find a result after 20 tries, it fails.
If your guess is 10 percent and `Rate` fails, try a different value for `Guess`.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the total number of payment periods in the annuity.
For example, if you make monthly payments on a four-year car loan, your loan has a total of 4 * 12 (or 48) payment periods.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the payment to be made each period.
Payments usually contain principal and interest that doesn't change over the life of the annuity.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the present value, or value today, of a series of future payments or receipts.
For example, when you borrow money to buy a car, the loan amount is the present value to the lender of the monthly car payments you will make.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifies the future value or cash balance you want after you make the final payment.
For example, the future value of a loan is $0 because that is its value after the final payment.
However, if you want to save $50,000 over 18 years for your child's education, then $50,000 is the future value.
If omitted, 0 is assumed.
Optional.
Object of type <xref href="Microsoft.VisualBasic.DueDate"></xref> that specifies when payments are due.
This argument must be either `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` if payments are due at the end of the payment period, or `DueDate.BegOfPeriod` if payments are due at the beginning of the period.
If omitted, `DueDate.EndOfPeriod` is assumed.
Optional.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying value you estimate is returned by <xref uid="langword_csharp_Rate" name="Rate" href=""></xref>.
If omitted, `Guess` is 0.1 (10 percent).
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the interest rate per period for an annuity.
NPer <= 0.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the straight-line depreciation of an asset for a single period.
The depreciation period must be expressed in the same unit as the `Life` argument.
All arguments must be positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying initial cost of the asset.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying value of the asset at the end of its useful life.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying length of the useful life of the asset.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the straight-line depreciation of an asset for a single period.
Life = 0.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the sum-of-years digits depreciation of an asset for a specified period.
The `Life` and `Period` arguments must be expressed in the same units.
For example, if `Life` is given in months, `Period` must also be given in months.
All arguments must be positive numbers.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the initial cost of the asset.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the value of the asset at the end of its useful life.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the length of the useful life of the asset.
Required.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the period for which asset depreciation is calculated.
Returns a <xref uid="langword_csharp_Double" name="Double" href=""></xref> specifying the sum-of-years digits depreciation of an asset for a specified period.
Salvage < 0, Period > Life, or Period <=0.
